DataElement.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography Emission Scan Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of positron emission tomography emission scan series obtained.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Device-In-Use Domain Positron Emission Tomography Emission scan
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to device-in-use._A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered._The usual mode of scanner operation in which a tracer's distribution throughout a subject is detected for subsequent processing into an image.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to device-in-use.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to device-in-use.

Property.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.:The usual mode of scanner operation in which a tracer's distribution throughout a subject is detected for subsequent processing into an image.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
The usual mode of scanner operation in which a tracer's distribution throughout a subject is detected for subsequent processing into an image.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The type of PET emission scan performed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term used to denote that something is unchanging, not dynamic.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The collection of image frames in a specific series over contiguous time intervals.
The collection of image frames of the body in a specific series over a contiguous time intervals where the whole body is scanned.
